discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The Label Distribution Protocol (LDP) can also be secured with MD-5 authentication across the MPLS cloud. This prevents hackers from introducing bogus routers, which would participate in the LDP.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/net_mgmt/vpn_solutions_center/2-0/mpls/provisioning/guide/PGmpls1.html

Selected Answer: D
The correct answer is D.

Since the goal is to prevent fake routers, i.e. hackers, from impersonating the CE, I think you need to use BGP MD-5 authentication on the PE.

LDP is used for protection between PE and P, making it difficult for hackers to impersonate PE or P.

Selected Answer: C
C is corerct

yes, the give anwser is correct

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The main difference between the two is that ISATAP is designed for transporting IPv6 packets within a site, while auto-tunnel can be used between sites.

comments.content: The tunnel mode ipv6ip isatap is used in the context of IPv6 transition technologies. Specifically, it refers to the ISATAP (Intra-Site Automatic Tunnel Addressing Protocol), which allows IPv6 packets to be transmitted over an IPv4 network.

discussion.content: it seems 6to4 is best suited for when you need spoke to spoke communication: An automatic 6to4 tunnel may be configured on a border router in an isolated IPv6 network, which creates a tunnel on a per-packet basis to a border router in another IPv6 network over an IPv4 infrastructure. The tunnel destination is determined by the IPv4 address of the border router extracted from the IPv6 address that starts with the prefix 2002::/16, where the format is 2002:border-router-IPv4-address ::/48. Following the embedded IPv4 address are 16 bits that can be used to number networks within the site. The border router at each end of a 6to4 tunnel must support both the IPv4 and IPv6 protocol stacks. 6to4 tunnels are configured between border routers or between a border router and a host.

Selected Answer: A
the goal is to enable both IPv4 and IPv6 traffic to be tunneled over an IPv6 network. The tunnel mode ipv6ip 6to4 configuration is specifically designed to facilitate this by allowing the encapsulation of IPv4 packets within an IPv6 tunnel

comments.content: Good catch. I will go with B.
Isn't Both 6to4 and autotunnel IPv6 tunneled inside IPv4??????

About the mode 6to4 ==> "6to4 tunneling" is an IPv6 transition mechanism described in RFC 3056. Like many other transition mechanisms, it enables encapsulation of IPv6 packets into IPv4 for transport across an IPv4 network.

IPv4-compatible
This is not a Cisco recommend tunnel type, though it is supported in IOS. As compared to Manual tunnels and GRE tunnels above, IPv4-compatible tunnels are point-to-multipoint where the previous two are simple point-to-point.

Automatic IPv4-compatible tunnels use IPv4-compatible IPv6 addresses. IPv4-compatible IPv6 addresses are IPv6 unicast addresses that have zeros in the high-order 96 bits of the address, and an IPv4 address in the low-order 32 bits. They can be written as 0:0:0:0:0:0:A.B.C.D or ::A.B.C.D, where “A.B.C.D” represents the embedded IPv4 address.

discussion.content:
It's B with the command tunnel mode ipv6ip 6to4 basically you incapsulate IPv6 packets into ipv4 packet for traversing an IPv4 network.

The question here is the opposite I think they are asking to us that they are migrating in IPv6 and so we need to incapsulate IPv4 packets into IPv6 packets in some cases.

So the command that allow us to do so is tunnel mode ipv6ip auto-tunnel, this command allows you to use ipv4 addresses that will be compatible with ipv6

Selected Answer: B
B is correct
B is correct answer

Selected Answer: B
tunnel mode ipv6ip isatap does not support multicast and it is used for intra-sites

Selected Answer: B
option B:
https://netcraftsmen.com/ccie-rs-prep-ipv6-part-2/

comments.content:
I doubt that cisco would want the answer "B" with "tunnel mode ipv6ip auto-tunnel".
I think that the best fit is "A" "tunnel mode ipv6ip 6to4", however, "D" ISATAP could be an option, too. 
Question mentions the ability to "add spoke routers automatically to the multicast NHRP mappings" -> I am not sure that it would work with ISATAP.
It is hard to decide on the answer without testing dmvpn+6to4 and ISATAP. It think that such a lab is out of scope for ENARSI. 

All of these are IPv6 over IPv4 tunnel technologies, but the question requests "DMVPN tunnel over the IPv6 network". 
I wonder if the question is written correctly.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Quick overview:
IPv6 Automatic IPv4-Compatible Tunnels (and also point-to-multipoint):
 IPv4-compatible: tunnel mode ipv6ip auto-tunnel -> not recommended either by Cisco nor by IETF/rfc7059
 More details:
 https://netcraftsmen.com/ccie-rs-prep-ipv6-part-2/
 https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7059#section-3.2
 https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/interface/configuration/15-s/ir-15-s-book/ip6-auto-comp-tun.pdf
 
 6to4: tunnel mode ipv6ip 6to4 -> for site-to-site/branch-to-branch 
 Limitations: no IGP support, only static route or BGP
 
 6RD: 6RD builds upon the 6to4 tunneling mechanism, and is designed for ISPs (for provider core) -> not for Branch-to-Branch
 
 ISATAP: tunnel mode ipv6ip isatap -> designed for intrasite tunneling (within a site/branch), still can be run between sites, too
 Limitations: -no IPv6 multicast, OSPFv3, EIGRP: neighbors are formed manually with "neighbor" command
 or need to use static route

Selected Answer: B
tunnel mode ipv6ip auto-tunnel
Example:
Router(config-if)# tunnel mode ipv6ip
auto-tunnel

Selected Answer: D
Based on the document from ellen_AA, I vote for answer D

Selected Answer: B
Given answer is correct
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/interface/configuration/15-s/ir-15-s-book/ip6-auto-comp-tun.pdf

questions.question_text:
A customer is running an mGRE DMVPN tunnel over WAN infrastructure between hub and spoke sites. The existing configuration allows NHRP to add spoke routers automatically to the multicast NHRP mappings. The customer is migrating the network from IPv4 to the IPv6 addressing scheme for those spokes' routers that support IPv6 and can run DMVPN tunnel over the IPv6 network.

Which configuration must be applied to support IPv4 and IPv6 DMVPN tunnels on spoke routers?

choices.C: Configure OSPF link cost to 1 between R1 and R2.
choices.D: Configure OSPF path cost to 3 between R1 and R2.
choices.A: Configure R1 and R2 LAN links as nonpassive.
choices.B: Configure R1 and R2 links under area 1.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which action ensures that 10.10.10.0/24 reaches 10.10.20.0/24 through the direct link between R1 and R2?

comments.content: very tricky, I dont even noticed that the link was part of Area 1! thanks, Agree its B
Thank you for your detailed answer.

Great solution! Well explained!
https://networklessons.com/ospf/ospf-path-selection-explained
OSPF will first look at the “type of path” to make a decision and, secondly look at the metric (cost).

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Both given routes are in area1, direct link is in area0. By default ospf prefers intra-area routes 'O' over inter-area routes 'O IA'. Bringing the direct link to the same area as both routes will make it preferable.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

answer is B.
it is because 10.10.20.0/24 is advertised via area 1. in r1 perspective,it have both type 3 LSA inter-area route advertised by R2 and intra-area route computed by type 1 LSA.

R1 will choose intra area route so that traffic will go to R4 instead of R1 no matter what cost is the direct link of area 0.

Selected Answer: B
OSPF route prerence.
Intra-Area, Inter-Area, external.
Takes precedence over metric
How do we know if they are not in the same area 1 for sure? Wouldn't that be easier to configure cost to 3 for example?
why not C , please advise

questions.question_text:
The summary route is not shown in the Router_B routing table after this below configuration on Router_A:

interface ethernet 0
description location ID:S4318T3E77F02
ip address 192.168.3.1 255.255.255.0
ip summary-address eigrp 1 172.16.80.0 255.255.240.0

Which Router_A configuration resolves the issue by advertising the summary route to Router_B?

discussion.content: We need to add a loopback interface that belongs to the subnet 172.16.80.0 255.255.240.0

Selected Answer: C
A subnetting question. How cute!

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Selected Answer: C
Will only advertise a summary if there is valid address within it in the RIB.

C is the only address in the summary range.

Selected Answer: C
correct
I don't understand this question, can someone please explain?

comments.content:
Summary addresses won't show in the routing table unless there's a componant route in the summary address range

Another way of asking this question would be "which of the following loopback ip addresses are contained in the 172.16.80.0 255.255.240.0 summary address"

A - 172.18.81.1 - is not in the summary as it has to be 172.16.80.0 - 172.16.95.255
B - 172.16.79.1 - is just under the summary
D - 172.16.96.1 - is just over the summary

Only C is in that range, which triggers the summary address to go into the routing table
